column6: oldest fossil from Patagonia; 20-22 MYA; Fordyce, R.E. and de MUIZON, C., 2001. Evolutionary history of cetaceans: a review. Secondary adaptation of tetrapods to life in water, pp.169-233.
African ancestor but I believe evolution/origin of family was on Madagascar
oldest fossil is known from Antartica Eocene

Originated in Eurasia or Africa; Ammerman, L.K., Lee, D.N. and Tipps, T.M., 2012. First molecular phylogenetic insights into the evolution of free-tailed bats in the subfamily Molossinae (Molossidae, Chiroptera). Journal of Mammalogy, 93(1), pp.12-28.
earliest record from east pacific; now only reside in actic; lknown also from atlantic subarctic records

North America or Eurasia; Hassanin, A. and Douzery, E.J., 2003. Molecular and morphological phylogenies of Ruminantia and the alternative position of the Moschidae. Systematic biology, 52(2), pp.206-228.

either Africa, Eurasia, or Insular (Philippines); Aghová, T., Kimura, Y., Bryja, J., Dobigny, G., Granjon, L. and Kergoat, G.J., 2018. Fossils know it best: using a new set of fossil calibrations to improve the temporal phylogenetic framework of murid rodents (Rodentia: Muridae). Molecular Phylogenetics and Evolution, 128, pp.98-111.
not enough fossils; now endemic to southern oceans
walruses; Many fossils found from the Pacific (western USA)
Oldest fossils in North America, but some hypotheses point to Eurasia as the origin. Still unresolved.
column7: Rocha, R.G., Leite, Y.L.R., Costa, L.P. and Rojas, D., 2016. Independent reversals to terrestriality in squirrels (Rodentia: Sciuridae) support ecologically mediated modes of adaptation. Journal of evolutionary biology, 29(12), pp.2471-2479.

column6: note: thought to have diverged from North America ancestor, but think Solenodontidae and Nesophontidae likely evolved on Caribbean islands
